msItem.note: Catalogue no. 3; Nelson collection no. N257. If this ostracon is correctly dated and if it concerns burial tax, then this may be one of several choachytes named Horos listed in Pestman (1993), p. 14-25. The phrase in lines 3 and 6 is reminiscent of the qualification of the deceased in early Ptolemaic burial tax receipts, "who was brought to the necropolis." 70 deben is 1400 drachmas, an enormous sum if calculated on the silver standard, compared to the 1 drachma or 7 obols normally paid for the burial tax in the early Ptolemaic period. Therefore, it was probably calculated on the copper standard used after 210 B.C.
The word or name in line 5 is preserved, but Muhs could not propose a plausible reading. The number of debens in line 5 runs over the edge of the ostracon and is illegible.
Source of description: On recto: accounts
